docs.title: Amplify Gen 2 Workshop
docs.text: Welcome to the AWS Amplify Gen 2 Workshop!

docs.title: Workshop Overview
docs.text:
In this workshop, you’ll be introduced to the fundamentals of AWS Amplify Gen 2. Using Amplify’s new code-first developer experience, you’ll learn how to build a fullstack application. You'll learn how to set up authentication, create a GraphQL API with real-time subscriptions, implement file storage, and deploy your application to the cloud.

What you'll build: A social media app where users can create, edit, and delete posts with images.

Technologies used:

  • React + TypeScript
  • AWS Amplify Gen 2
    • AWS Cognito (Authentication)
    • AWS AppSync (GraphQL API)
    • Amazon DynamoDB (Database)
    • Amazon S3 (File Storage)

docs.title: Workshop Elements
docs.text: Key elements and components of this workshop.

docs.title: What is AWS Amplify?
docs.text: AWS Amplify is a comprehensive set of tools and services that enable developers to build secure, scalable, full-stack web and mobile applications. It streamlines both frontend and backend development by integrating seamlessly with various AWS services.

docs.title: Core Features of AWS Amplify
docs.text:
• Backend-as-a-Service (BaaS): Rapidly create and manage backends with support for authentication, data storage, APIs, and more.
  • Frontend Integration: Easily connect your backend to web and mobile frameworks like React, Next.js, Vue, Angular, iOS, and Android.
  • Hosting: Fully managed CI/CD and static web hosting powered by AWS CloudFront for fast global delivery.

docs.title: Amplify Modules and Services Overview
docs.text:
1. Authentication

    • Powered by Amazon Cognito
    • Features: User sign-up, sign-in, multi-factor authentication, and social login (Google, Facebook, etc.)

  2. Data (Amplify Data)

    • Uses AWS AppSync (GraphQL) or API Gateway + Lambda (REST)
    • Real-time APIs with subscriptions
    • Type-safe client generation for web and mobile

  3. Storage

    • File storage using Amazon S3
    • Data storage using Amazon DynamoDB or RDS (via Lambda)
    • Fine-grained access control with Cognito user roles

  4. Functions

    • Serverless logic using AWS Lambda
    • Triggered by events (e.g., API requests, file uploads, or time-based events)

  5. Hosting

    • Continuous deployment via GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, or AWS CodeCommit
    • Global CDN via Amazon CloudFront
    • Custom domains, redirects, and access control

  6. Notifications

    • Push notifications using Amazon Pinpoint
    • Email, SMS, and in-app messaging support

  7. Analytics

    • Built-in tracking of user sessions and behavior via Amazon Pinpoint

  8. Geo

    • Maps, geofencing, and location tracking powered by Amazon Location Service

docs.title: Benefits of AWS Amplify
docs.text:
• Accelerated Development: Scaffolding and code generation for backend services and APIs
  • Unified Workflow: Manage frontend and backend from a single project
  • Flexible and Extensible: Built on top of standard AWS services
  • Cross-Platform: Supports web, iOS, Android, and cross-platform frameworks like React Native

docs.title: Amplify Hosting Highlights
docs.text:
• Automatic Git-Based Deployments: Connect your repo for auto-deploys on every push
  • Instant Previews: Preview pull requests before merging
  • Custom Domains & HTTPS: Easy domain setup with free SSL
  • Scalable Infrastructure: Backed by AWS infrastructure for performance and reliability

In the next section, we will explore the differences between Amplify Gen 1 and Gen 2 — including changes in architecture, workflows, and developer experience.

docs.title: What is AWS?
docs.text:
Amazon Web Services (AWS) is a comprehensive cloud platform offering infrastructure and tools to help developers build scalable, reliable, and cost-efficient applications. Instead of managing physical servers or complex setups, developers can use AWS to streamline deployment, security, data storage, and user authentication.

In this workshop, we’ll explore how AWS, especially through its serverless services and AWS Amplify, streamlines the modern web development workflow and empowers developers to focus on building features rather than managing infrastructure.

docs.title: What is Serverless?
docs.text: Serverless computing allows developers to build applications without managing servers. AWS handles the provisioning, scaling, and maintenance behind the scenes.

docs.title: Key characteristics:
docs.text:
• No Servers to Manage – Write and deploy code without touching infrastructure.
  • Automatic Scaling – Applications respond to demand without manual intervention.
  • Pay-per-Use – You’re only charged when your code runs or when resources are used.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• Developer Productivity – Focus on features and the actual code, less of infrastructure.
  • Cost-Efficient – Avoid idle costs; only pay for what you use.
  • Built-in Reliability and Scalability – Services adjust automatically to usage patterns.

docs.title: Solves Traditional Infrastructure Problems
docs.text: Traditional Problem Serverless Solution Manual Scaling Auto-scaling built into services High Maintenance Costs No server patching or upkeep needed Complexity in Setup Minimal configuration using AWS tools Expensive Infrastructure Efficient, event-driven pricing model

docs.title: From Traditional Web Development to Modern Cloud Solutions
docs.text:
In the early days of web development, building and hosting websites required extensive manual setup and maintenance. Developers and system administrators had to handle everything, from server provisioning to code deployment, to ensure the site remained functional, secure, and accessible. While this approach offered complete control, it also came with major challenges as web applications evolved into more dynamic and user-driven.

These led to challenges such as:

  • Scaling Difficulties: Handling sudden traffic spikes required manually adding new servers and complex configurations, increasing both workload and risk of human error.
  • High Maintenance Overhead: Teams had to continuously monitor performance, apply updates, and maintain uptime, often diverting focus from actual feature development.
  • Cost and Resource Intensity: Running and maintaining servers demanded specialized personnel and generated ongoing operational expenses.

It became clear that the traditional model could not keep up with modern, fast-paced development demands. The industry needed a solution that automated these infrastructure concerns, and this is where AWS comes in.

docs.title: Key Differences Between Amplify Gen 1 and Gen 2
docs.text: AWS Amplify Gen 2 introduces a TypeScript-based, code-first approach to building full-stack applications, improving speed, developer experience (DX), and workflow efficiency compared to Amplify Gen 1.

docs.title: Core Comparison
docs.text: Feature Amplify Gen 1 Amplify Gen 2 Infrastructure Setup CLI or Amplify Studio TypeScript files (e.g., resource.ts) Developer Experience Manual provisioning IDE-friendly with IntelliSense and type safety Local Development Shared environments Isolated sandboxes per developer (faster, safer iterations) Environment Management Manual CLI/console setup Git branch = environment (zero-config setup) Frontend Type Integration Requires codegen for types Auto-generated types for real-time data binding Workflow Integration Backend-focused Fullstack-first: backend, hosting, auth, UI all unified API & DB Definition JSON-based GraphQL schema TypeScript-based schema with live code integration Authentication AWS Cognito with CLI setup Cognito via TS config with extendable user flows Custom AWS Services Limited/extensible via CLI Built on AWS CDK — fully modular and extensible Management Console Basic deployment and hosting Unified view of builds, hosting, env vars, users, data

docs.title: Key Amplify Gen 2 Features
docs.text:
• TypeScript-first fullstack development
  • Real-time API & NoSQL DB auto-generated from TS schema
  • Git-based environments (e.g., main, dev, feature/*)
  • Instant preview deploys from pull requests
  • Cognito Auth with simple custom user flows
  • AWS CDK foundation for modular extension (e.g., S3, Lambda, Location)

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Amplify Gen 2 modernizes the app development lifecycle by:

  • Replacing manual backend configuration with code-first workflows
  • Speeding up development using cloud sandboxes
  • Reducing setup time with Git-integrated environments
  • Enhancing reliability and collaboration with TypeScript-powered tooling

We will now proceed with the actual workshop using Amplify Gen 2, where we’ll walk through creating a real-time API, setting up authentication, and deploying your fullstack app from scratch.

docs.title: Create a React and Vite App
docs.text:
First step is creating a Frontend Application. But worry less, we have prepared one for you to follow easily.

All you have to do is to create the repository using our GitHub template below:

Create repository from template

  • The repository have branches named step-1, step-2, etc. to serve as checkpoints.
  • Each branch reflects a stage in the workshop, in case you get lost later on.

After that, you now have a copy of the workshop repository

docs.title: Clone the Repository Locally
docs.text:
Now, clone the repository you just created to your local machine.

  1. Open your terminal

  2. Navigate to any folder where you want to keep your project:

    cd /Projects

  3. Clone the repository using the URL from GitHub (replace and accordingly): 

    git clone https://github.com/<your-username>/<repo-name>.git

  4. Change directory into the project folder:

    cd <repo-name>

  5. Checkout the starting branch:

    git checkout step-1

  6. Install dependencises:

    npm install

  7. Start the local development server:

    npm run dev

    8. Your copy of the Workshop App should now be running locally at http://localhost:5173/

docs.title: Deploying a React App with AWS Amplify
docs.text:
Now that we’ve created our frontend React application, it’s time to make it accessible on the internet! Using AWS Amplify, we can connect our project to a GitHub repository and deploy it in just a few steps.

With Amplify, you don’t need to manually configure servers and hosting. Amplify handles all the cloud infrastructure for you. This means your app can be live online quickly with minimal setup.

docs.title: Steps to Deploy
docs.text:
1. Go to the AWS Amplify Console Open the Amplify Console.

  2. Click "Create App" or "Deploy" You'll find this option on the homepage of the Amplify dashboard.

  3. Select GitHub as your Git provider Amplify supports GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and CodeCommit.

  4. Authorize Amplify to access your GitHub account This is a one-time GitHub App authorization.

  5. Select your repository Pick the repo containing your React app from the list.

  6. Choose the branch to deploy Usually main or master, depending on your project.

  7. (Optional) Configure app settings You can customize build settings or just click Next to skip.

  8. Review settings and click "Save and Deploy" Amplify will start the deployment process.

  9. Wait for the build to complete After a few minutes, your app will be live on an Amplify-hosted URL

With just a few clicks, you’ve connected your code repository, configured the deployment, and let AWS Amplify handle all the cloud infrastructure. From here, any future updates you push to your GitHub branch will automatically trigger a new deployment, keeping your app live and up-to-date.

This demonstrates the power and simplicity of Amplify, letting you focus on building features instead of worrying about servers, hosting, or CI/CD pipelines.

Now that your frontend is live, we can now implement some backend functionality using Amplify Gen 2!

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Ensure you have the following before starting:

  • NodeJS v18+
  • AWS Account
  • GitHub Account
  • IDE (preferably Visual Studio)

docs.title: NodeJS v18+ Installation
docs.text:
One way to install Node.js is through a package manager. Every operating system has its own. You can find a list of installation methods for macOS, Linux, and Windows here: https://nodejs.org/download/package-manager/

To verify installation, run:

node -v
npm -v

If both commands return version numbers (e.g., v18.x.x and 9.x.x), you’re all set.

docs.title: Installing the AWS Amplify CLI
docs.text:
The Amplify CLI is a command-line tool that helps you set up and manage your Amplify backend, including authentication, data models, storage, and deployment.

Install the Amplify CLI globally using npm:

npm install -g @aws-amplify/cli
Once installation completes, configure the CLI so it can access your AWS resources:

amplify configure

Running this command will:

  1. Open the AWS Console in your browser.

  2. Guide you through creating a new IAM user specifically for Amplify.

  3. Ask you to generate Access Keys for this IAM user.

  4. Prompt you to enter those Access Keys back into your terminal.

By completing this setup, the CLI can securely interact with your AWS account to deploy and manage your resources.

docs.title: Setting Up AWS Amplify for Your App
docs.text:
With AWS Amplify, we can add backend capabilities to our application with just a single command. The quickstart npm create amplify@latest can automatically generate an Amplify project with preconfigured folders and resources.

But to give you a deeper understanding of Amplify Gen 2, we won’t use the automatic generator today. Instead, we’ll build the backend step-by-step, giving us full control and a cleaner foundation for learning.

docs.title: Manual Installation of Amplify Gen 2
docs.text:
1. Install the necessary Amplify Gen 2 module:

    npm init -y
npm add --save-dev @aws-amplify/backend@latest @aws-amplify/backend-cli@latest typescript

    This creates our package.json for the backend and installs our Amplify Gen 2 dependencies

  2. In your project folder, create and navigate to a new amplify directory: 

    mkdir amplify
cd amplify

  3. Initialize our backend configuration files:

    Inside the amplify/ folder, create:

    • backend.ts - main entry for our Amplify resources

      import { defineBackend } from '@aws-amplify/backend';

defineBackend({});

    • tsconfig.json - basic TypeScript configuration

      {
    "extends": "@aws-amplify/backend/tsconfig"
}

docs.title: Final Folder Structure
docs.text:
After those steps, it will scaffold your project with the following structure:

├── amplify/
│   ├── backend.ts              # Main backend entry
│   ├── tsconfig.json           # TypeScript config
│   └── package.json            # Describes our dependencies
├── node_modules/
├── .gitignore
├── package-lock.json
├── package.json
└── tsconfig.json

At this point, you’ve successfully set up the Amplify backend for your project. Your project is now ready for the next steps, where we’ll add features like authentication, data, and storage.

docs.title: Adding Amplify Auth
docs.text:
Amplify Auth uses Amazon Cognito under-the-hood. Cognito is an Amazon service that is built to handle user registration, authentication, andother such operations.

To get started, we shall define our authentication resource. Create an auth resource file amplify/auth/resource.ts

export const auth = defineAuth({
    loginWith: {
        email
})

By default, the auth resource is configured to use email as its login method. You can use a different configuration for your projects but for this workshop, we will be using the simplest configuration.

After defining auth resource, pass it to your amplify/backend.ts 

import { defineBackend } from '@aws-amplify/backend';
import { auth } from './auth/resource';

defineBackend({
  auth,
});

docs.title: Deploying Auth Resource
docs.text:
After defining your auth resource, create your resource in your personal cloud sandbox. This deploys your backend resources in a safe, isolated environment.

Run the following command:

npx ampx sandbox

Following a successful deployment, the command generates an outputs file amplify_outputs.json. This file serves as a connection between your frontend app and your backend resources.

What happens when you run this command?

  • Amplify reads your backend definitions (like auth/resource.ts).

  • Amplify provisions the resources you defined. For Auth, this includes a Cognito User Pool, Identity Pool, and related authentication infrastructure in your sandbox environment.

  • Once deployment is successful, it generates a file called amplify_outputs.json. This contains all the configuration details and resource identifiers your frontend needs to communicate with the backend.

docs.title: Connecting your Frontend to your Auth Resource
docs.text:
Navigate to your main app /src/App.tsx and add the following lines:

import { Amplify } from 'aws-amplify';
import outputs from '../amplify_outputs.json';

Amplify.configure(outputs);     // Connects your backend to your frontend

Amplify.configure(outputs) reads the outputs file and automatically sets up connections to all your deployed backend resources (in this case, authentication).

Congratulations. Now your React App has been connected to your Amplify backend!

docs.title: Implementing Authentication
docs.text:
Now let's add a frontend interface to implement our Authentication.

Creating a sign-in form and implement the right flow can be time-consuming and challenging. With Amplify's Authenticator UI component, we can think less of the authentication flow. The components works along with the configuration in your amplify/auth/resource.ts to automatically connect to your backend resources.

First step would be to install the @aws-amplify/ui-react library:

npm add @aws-amplify/ui-react

After successfall installation, navigate to your src/App.tsx and import the Authenticator Component and Amplify's styles.css.

import { Authenticator } from '@aws-amplify/ui-react';
import '@aws-amplify/ui-react/styles.css';

Then wrap your App with the Authenticator tags in your return function.

<Authenticator>
    <main>
        <User />
        <Posts />
    </main>
</Authenticator>

After wrapping our App with Amplify's Authenticator, a built-in Sign-up page with a configured authentication flow will be shown when we are not authenticated thanks to Amplify Authenticator UI:

Screenshot here

If we are able to sign-in, we should be able to sign-out as well. Navigate to components/User.tsx. This is our top component after successfuly signing-in. Using the @aws-amplify/ui-react, import the useAuthenticator hook

import { useAuthenticator } from "@aws-amplify/ui-react";

Use that hook to give us access to our signed user information and the signOut function. Replace lines accordingly: 

  const { user, signOut } = useAuthenticator();
  const username = user?.signInDetails?.loginId;

  return (
    <div className="user-container">
      <h1>Hi, {username}</h1>
      <button onClick={signOut}>Sign Out</button>
    </div>
  )
}

After saving the changes, we are able to display the logged-in user's email and a working Sign Out button.

Screenshot here

Authentication has never been this easy. That is Amplify Auth for you!

docs.title: Cognito User Management
docs.text: Once you’ve added authentication to your application using Amplify, your backend is essentially powered by Amazon Cognito under-the-hood. This securely manages user accounts, authentication flows, and user data. In this section, we’ll explore how to view and manage users directly in the Amplify Console.

docs.title: What is Amazon Cognito?
docs.text:
Amazon Cognito is a fully managed service that handles:

  • User sign-up and sign-in
  • Multi-factor authentication (MFA)
  • User pools (authentication) and identity pools (authorization)
  • Social logins (Google, Facebook, Apple, etc.)
  • Secure token generation for your frontend apps

When you define an Auth resource in Amplify, Cognito automatically creates the required User Pool and Identity Pool in the cloud sandbox.

docs.title: Viewing Users in the Amplify Console
docs.text:
After deploying your auth resource via npx ampx sandbox, you can view and manage users from the Amplify Dashboard.

  1. Open the Amplify Console in your browser.
  2. Select your deployed app from the list of applications.
  3. Choose the deployed branch you want to manage (e.g., main or dev).
  4. Click on “Authentication” in the sidebar to access your Auth resources and view all users.

docs.title: Managing Users
docs.text:
In the Authentication section of the Amplify Console, you can view all registered users. By clicking on a specific user, you can access detailed information and manage their account directly.

  • View usernames, email addresses, and sign-up status
  • Enable or disable accounts
  • Reset user passwords
  • Force email verification
  • Assign users to groups for role-based access control

This interface gives you full visibility and control over the users in your app without writing any backend code.

docs.title: Enable Multi-Factor Authentication
docs.text: Setting up multi-factor authentication (MFA).

docs.title: Creating a Post
docs.text:
Now that we've configured our data backend, we can now implement CRUD operations. For this section, we will be implementing the Create operation for our app.

Navigate to components/Posts.tsx and do the following:

Step 1: Import Schema and Generate Client

import type { Schema } from '../amplify/data/resource'
import { generateClient } from 'aws-amplify/data'

const client = generateClient<Schema>()
A TypeScript schema is generated based on your Amplify backend. With generateClient<Schema>(), a typed Amplify Data client is created, which can perform:

  • create()
  • update()
  • delete()
  • list()

Step 2: Set Up Posts State

const [posts, setPosts] = useState<Schema["Post"]["type"][]>([]);
posts state will hold all the posts we fetch or create. Initially, it’s empty.

Step 3: Define the Create Function

const createPost = async () => {
  const title = window.prompt("Title: ");
  if (!title) return;

  try {
    const newPost = await client.models.Post.create({
      title,
      email: user.signInDetails?.loginId,
      date: new Date().toLocaleString(),
    });

    console.log("Posted Successfully: ", newPost);

  } catch(error) {
    console.log("Error: ", error})
  }
};
  • The function starts with prompting for a title name.
  • The .create() method sends the new post data to your backend.
  • Amplify handles storing it in DynamoDB via AppSync, including any authorization rules you defined.
  • After a successful call, newPost contains the record returned from the backend, confirming the post was saved.

Step 4: Add the onClick function to existing button to trigger createPost

<button onClick={createPost}>Add Post+</button>

Step 5: Confirm if working

After clicking the button, check your terminal.

Posted Successfully: ...

If logs return a value like above, it means it is working

Congrats, you now have created a Post successfuly!

docs.title: Set up Amplify Data
docs.text: With Amplify Data, you can quickly create a secure, real-time API with a database. Just define your data model in TypeScript, and Amplify sets up the API using AWS AppSync and DynamoDB. You can secure it with rules and add custom features with AWS Lambda.

docs.title: Building your data backend
docs.text:
To get started, we shall define our data resource. Create an auth resource file amplify/data/resource.ts and fill it with the following:

import { a, defineData, type ClientSchema } from '@aws-amplify/backend';

const schema = a.schema({
  Post: a.model({
    title: a.string(),
    email: a.string(),
    userId: a.string(),
    date: a.string(),
    imageKey: a.string()
  })
    .authorization(allow => [
      allow.authenticated().to(['read']),
    ])
});

// used for code completion / highlighting when making requests from frontend
export type Schema = ClientSchema<typeof schema>;

// defines the data resource to be deployed
export const data = defineData({
  schema,
  authorizationModes: {
    defaultAuthorizationMode: 'userPool',
  }
});

Don't forget to pass it to your amplify/backend.ts 

import { defineBackend } from '@aws-amplify/backend';
import { auth } from './auth/resource';
import { data } from './data/resource';

defineBackend({
  auth,
  data,
});

docs.title: Code Breakdown
docs.text:
schema

a is Amplify's backend builder that allow us to define schemas, models, fields, etc. With that, we defined a schema where it has a model named Post with the fields: title, email, date that will be used to populate our frontend content later.

authorization rules 

.authorization(allow => [
    allow.authenticated().to(['read']),
])
This tells Amplify that only signed-in-users can read posts.

ClientSchema

This generates TypeScript types for the frontend. This provides type-checking and autocomplete for Amplify objects. Not required but helps with development.

defineData

This creates the data backend configuration: - AppSync GraphQL API - DynamoDB tables - Realtime subscriptions - API authentication using Cognito User Pools

defaultAuthorizationMode tells Amplify which method to use when authorizing every API request. Setting it to 'userPool' means the API will require a valid Cognito User Pool token, so only authenticated users can interact with your data backend unless you define additional authorization rules.

With your data backend now fully defined and connected to Amplify, you’re ready to start implementing create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) operations in your frontend.

docs.title: Deleting a Post
docs.text:
Now we'll implement the Delete operation to allow users to remove their posts.

Navigate to components/Posts.tsx and do the following:

Step 1: Define the Delete Function

const deletePost = async (id: string) => {
  try {
    const deletedPost = await client.models.Post.delete({
      id,
    })
    console.log("Deleted Successfully: ", deletedPost)
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error: ", error)
  }
}
  • The function takes the post id as a parameter to identify which post to delete
  • The .delete() method removes the post from your backend
  • Only requires the id field to perform the deletion

Step 2: Add Delete Button with Authorization

{isAuthor(userId!) &&
  <div className="post-buttons">
    <button onClick={() => editPost(id)}>Edit</button>
    <button onClick={() => deletePost(id)}>Remove</button>
  </div>
}
  • Uses the same isAuthor check to ensure only post authors can delete their posts
  • Passes the post id to the deletePost function when clicked

Step 3: Confirm if working

After clicking the Remove button, check your terminal.

Deleted Successfully: ...

If logs return a value like above, it means the deletion is working. The post should also disappear from the UI automatically due to the real-time subscription.

Congrats, you now have post deletion functionality!

docs.title: Updating a Post
docs.text:
Now we'll implement the Update operation to allow users to edit their existing posts.

Navigate to components/Posts.tsx and do the following:

Step 1: Define the Update Function

const editPost = async (id: string) => {
  try {
    const editedPost = await client.models.Post.update({
      id,
      title: window.prompt("Title?"),
      email: user.signInDetails?.loginId,
      userId: user.userId,
      date: new Date().toLocaleString(),
      imageKey: "",
    })
    console.log("Edited Successfully: ", editedPost)
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error: ", error)
  }
}
  • The function takes the post id as a parameter to identify which post to update
  • Prompts the user for a new title
  • The .update() method sends the updated data to your backend
  • Updates the timestamp to reflect when the edit was made

Step 2: Add Authorization Check

const isAuthor = (author: string) => {
  if (user.userId == author) {
    return true
  } else {
    return false
  }
}
  • Checks if the current user is the author of the post
  • Only authors can edit their own posts

Step 3: Add Edit Button with Conditional Rendering

{isAuthor(userId!) &&
  <div className="post-buttons">
    <button onClick={() => editPost(id)}>Edit</button>
  </div>
}
  • Only shows the Edit button if the current user is the post author
  • Passes the post id to the editPost function when clicked

Step 4: Confirm if working

After clicking the Edit button and entering a new title, check your terminal.

Edited Successfully: ...

If logs return a value like above, it means the update is working

Congrats, you now have post editing functionality!

docs.title: Reading Posts
docs.text:
Now we'll implement the Read operation to display all posts in real-time using Amplify's observeQuery feature.

Navigate to components/Posts.tsx and do the following:

Step 1: Set Up Real-time Subscription

useEffect(() => {
  const sub = client.models.Post.observeQuery().subscribe({
    next: ({ items }) => {
      setPosts([...items]);
    },
  });

  return () => sub.unsubscribe();
}, []);
  • observeQuery() creates a real-time subscription to your Post model
  • Whenever posts are created, updated, or deleted, the subscription automatically receives the latest data
  • The cleanup function unsubscribes when the component unmounts to prevent memory leaks

Step 2: Display Posts in JSX

{posts.map(({ id, title, email, userId, date, imageKey }) => (
  <div className="post" key={id}>
    <img src={imageKey || ""} />
    <h1 className="title">{title}</h1>
    <p className="user">{email}</p>
    <p className="date">{date}</p>
  </div>
))}
  • Maps through the posts array to render each post
  • Displays title, email, date, and image for each post
  • Uses the post id as the unique key for React rendering

Step 3: Confirm if working

After creating a post, you should see it appear automatically in the UI without refreshing the page.

Congrats, you now have real-time post reading functionality!
